lines.text: You know, every day I would pick a different memory of you and play it over and over and over again in my mind, until every hair, every freckle, every part of you was exactly as I remembered.
[Anne sees Gilbert and runs to meet him, but falls flat on her face]
Are you alright? Nothing broken or bent I hope.

[laughing]
Only my pride. Oh, Gil, help me up. I'm purely blind and a fool to boot! Oh, if I were blind, I should never forget the contours of your face. Why didn't you let me know?
Well, I wanted to see you face to face. I have something to ask you.
I do.
[kisses Gilbert]
Let's go take a walk down the lane!
[kiss each other again]
I've made up my mind to go to my grave unwept, unhonored and unsung.
But not unpublished.
But I keep thinking, if he was really dead, surely I would know that in my heart. I would feel a terrible... emptiness.
Marry me now. Let me go.
Everything I ever loved gets taken away.
You do what the rest of us only dream of doing, Anne.
No, true success requires passion and a vision. Not just dollars and sense, Mr. Owen.
You're going about it all topsy-turvy. You must absolutely always start with a firm premise and a solid ending.
Aim much higher creatively, if you want my opinion, Miss Shirley.
This is the most loving and generous thing anyone has ever done for me! It makes up for every unfulfilled dream I've ever contemplated!
What are you doing here?
I've been working as a war correspondent back and forth between London and Belgium for a year.
Putting the name Jack Garrison to good use?
Hasn't hurt. American papers love the sensation.
I'm sure they do.

[reading aloud to herself]
'Forever Into Eternity' by Anne Shirley.
You'll jinx yourself with titles like that, Miss Shirley.
[startles Anne]
Oh, don't be embarrassed. Half the people in this building are writing books on their lunch hour.
Y-y-you are, aren't you?
Jack Garrison.
It's a pleasure to meet you. All Mr.Owen ever talks about is your latest manuscript. 'Real page turner' according to him.
That's one way of putting it seeing he hasn't even seen it yet. Would you pass this material on to Mr. Owen. It's the story outline of my latest book according to the terms of my contract.
Certainly.
My lawyer will be following up before I go to draft.
[pause]
You know, I have a moment. Why don't you tell me about your story. Maybe I can help you come up with a decent title.
